content.webTitle: Chinese newspapers in joint call to end curb on migrant workers

fields.headline: Chinese newspapers in joint call to end curb on migrant workers
fields.bodyText: Thirteen Chinese newspapers launched a highly unusual joint appeal for social reforms today, attacking the country's household registration system, which limits the access of rural migrant workers to basic services in China's cities. "China has suffered from the hukou [household registration] system for so long," the appeal said. "We believe people are born free and should have the right to migrate freely, but citizens are still troubled by bad policies born in the era of the planned economy and [now] unsuitable." The appeal appeared to have been removed from at least one website this evening within hours, but was still available on other newspapers' sites. Hundreds of millions of Chinese workers have flocked from the countryside to cities since economic reforms began three decades ago, driving the country's staggering growth. But critics say the hukou system has created second-class citizens who often struggle to gain access to basic services such as health and education. Because the hukou is inherited, migrants' children suffer the same problems. Newspapers including the Metropolis Times of Kunming, the Southern Metropolis Daily, Chongqing Times and the Economic Observer ran the appeal in a rare co-ordinated action. They timed their call to coincide with the annual meetings of China's largely rubber-stamp legislature and advisory body, which begin this week, where the hukou is likely to be high on the agenda. Officials have already pledged changes and China's premier, Wen Jiabao, promised to push ahead with them in an internet chat yesterday. But the joint editorial urged delegates to the National People's Congress and Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference to hasten reforms with a view to ending the system. The hukou was introduced in the 1950s as a way of helping to manage the planned economy, but has weakened over the years. Some cities have begun allowing migrants to register as residents, giving them additional rights. Authorities fear a drastic overhaul could lead to an unmanageable influx of migrants into the main urban centres, increasing the strain on housing and services and potentially contributing to crime and unrest. The system also helps officials to keep track of individuals. Instead, the government wants to encourage rural dwellers to move to smaller cities in their own provinces. The editorial noted that the system also affects urban residents who move to other provinces – restricting their ability to get pensions and insurance – and breeds corruption, because people will pay large sums for a residence permit in cities such as Beijing. An article about the joint commentary, published on the Chinese website Sina, but credited to the Economic Observer, noted: "This is a rare and major event in domestic media, showing [its] strong wish to participate in and promote the process of China's reform." It explained that the editorial was inspired by a similar project led by the Guardian, in which 56 newspapers issued a joint call for action from world leaders on climate change ahead of the Copenhagen summit in December. "There is no doubt that what the media can do is 'advocating and urging'. The big men who hold power are the final decision-makers," it added. But it concluded: "We are not just witnesses, we are participants!" Yao Yang, deputy dean of China's National School of Development at Peking University, told the Financial Times: "I've never heard of Chinese newspapers jointly publishing an editorial on a specific policy matter like this. It is very unusual."
